results.title: How Much Car Insurance Do I Need? | Progressive
results.description: Like bodily injury liability coverage, your property damage liability limit (the third number) should cover what you have to lose. For instance, if you have $25,000 in property damage coverage and your net worth is greater than that, you're putting yourself at risk if you cause more than $25,000 worth of damage in an auto accident. Learn more about auto liability coverage. What does it cover? Comprehensive coverage protects your vehicle from things outside your control, such as theft, vandalism, fire, collisions with animals, glass breakage, and damage from weather.

results.title: How Are Speed Limits Set? | Progressive
results.description: Posted speed limits are indicated by signs posted along the road. Statutory speed limits are set when the type of road determines baseline speed limits. The state’s motor vehicle laws define statutory limits, which are applicable if there’s no posted speed limit.

results.title: Split-Limit Car Insurance Explained | Progressive
results.description: Example:Imagine you have liability coverage limits of 25/50/25. If you cause an accident, the other driver can file a claim with your insurance for up to $25,000 for their injuries alone. They can claim up to $50,000 in total for injuries they and anyone else involved in the accident have suffered, such as one of their passengers. They can also file a claim for damage to their vehicle for up to $25,000.

results.title: Multi-Car Insurance: How Does It Work? | Progressive
results.description: A multi-car insurance policy just means you have two or more vehicles on your policy. If you have more than one vehicle that you keep at the same address, you can add them all to your policy. Some insurance companies may state that they must be "garaged" at the same address, but an actual garage isn't required.

results.title: What Is a Motor Vehicle Record (MVR)? | Progressive
results.description: Your MVR, or motor vehicle record, pulls information regarding your driving history from your state's department or bureau of motor vehicles.
